page.title: 10CUSTOMS IN WITHYHAM/ST.JOHN
page.content: This{area}is on Ashdown{Forest}which includes common land 'owned by Lord Buckhurst. Commoners still have a right to the customary uses of the forest reflecting{traditions}dating from Saxon times. Commoners could collect windfall wood but not trees torn up by the roots as these belonged to the King. This timber could only be gathered between Hockday and Michaelmas. Brushwood, furze and broom could be collected for fuel or burnt to to create fresh pasture and it became tradition to fire the gorse for this purpose in Spring. Stock could graze on the forest except between Michaelmas and Martinmas. Swine could forage all year except during 'fence' month., the fawning time of the{deer. Commoners would put hay out for deer in winter and claim a couple of beech trees in return.
